awd_titl_txt: ICE-T:RC: Optimizing Internet video through support from the network edge
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite many advances in recent years, the performance of Internet video often falls below user expectations. The issues are likely to be exacerbated with the emergence of bandwidth-intensive 4K video, and more recently, interactive video such as 360-degree video which is latency sensitive as well.  This project investigates new opportunities opened by recent Internet Service Provider (ISP) interest in deploying value-added services at the edge of the provider's network. Such edge-based services can aid video streaming applications through lower latencies, higher throughput, and visibility into network performance
bottlenecks.

This project will explore novel services that may be deployed at the ISP edge, which can significantly improve the performance of video streaming solutions, as well as develop new approaches to video streaming that can leverage these services. The research will systematically characterize these benefits, develop new mechanisms, and consider practical deployment concerns. Specific research contributions will include: 1. Techniques for proactively estimating the rate at which video applications can transmit informed by explicit information collected at the network edge in real-time. The approach includes edge-based monitoring and estimation to ensure scalability, and extensive use of network data to refine and validate our algorithms.
2. Redesigning state-of-the-art available bit rate (ABR) approaches to exploit proactive rate estimation. The project team will also explore a new design point where the ABR algorithm itself is run on an edge server rather than the client.
3. Measurement-based characterization studies of interactive video streaming to investigate issues around edge support for interactive video. Specifically, the project will consider the interplay between the encoding scheme used for 360-degree video, user interactivity models, and the edge cache hit rate.  This project will extend an ongoing research collaboration between Purdue University and the Politecnico di Torino, Italy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Video traffic accounts for over 80% of all Internet traffic today. Despite much progress, the performance of Internet video often falls below expectations with users experiencing problems such as rebuffering. While access and core network capacity continues to grow, optimizing Internet video delivery will remain a challenge since we are only beginning to see the adoption of technologies such as 4K video which may involve bitrates of tens of Megabits per second, and since there exists (and will likely remain), a wide gulf in the quality of both fixed and mobile broadbandconnections across households globally.

The project explored novel services that may be deployed at the edge of Internet Service Providers which can significantly improve the performance of video streaming solutions, and has developed new approaches to video streaming that can leverage these services. The research systematically demonstrated these benefits through large-scale data analysis and measurements, and system prototypes.

Video streaming today typically involves splitting video into chunks, each encoded at multiple bitrates. Clients pick bitrates for each chunk so as to balance between achieving high video quality, while avoiding rebuffering.Several Adaptive Bitrate (ABR) algorithms have emerged to tackling this challenge.However, the design of these algorithms is complicated by the fact that clients must predict chunk download times,a challenging problem. Most research in video streaming typically assumes that chunk download times are primarily determined by network throughput, and use local algorithms based on observations of prior chunks to estimate throughput. Yet, predicting throughput is challenging, often leading to conservative low quality bitrate selections, or aggressive selections that result in rebuffering.

This project has made several contributions.

First, the project has shown through measurements of real video publishers that it is common for chunks in a video session to be served from different layers in the hierarchy of a Content Delivery Network (CDN). Further, the layer in the  hierarchy from which an object is served, and the Time to First Byte (TTFB) can impact throughput. While ABR algorithms today are agnostic as to where in a CDN hierarchy anobject is served from, we showed that incorporating CDN awareness reduces prediction error for 81.7% of sessions by 17.16%, and significantly improves video quality.

Second, the project developed Xatu, a custom neural network prediction framework for video streaming applications.Xatu considers static features that do not vary during a session (e.g., Internet Service Provider, CDN or city),and models sequences involving multiple temporal features that vary across chunks in a session (e.g., TTFB, throughput). Xatu reduces prediction errors relative to state-of-the-art by 24%, and when integrated with real ABR algorithms, improves a composite video quality metric by 39%.

Third, the project highlighted and quantified biases that may arise when using associational methods such as neural networks for predictions in interventional settings where a designer wishes to understand the impact of making a change to a deployed video streaming algorithm.

Fourth, the project tackled challenges in streaming live video in Unmanned Aerial Settings (UAS) over highly variable wireless links. The project showed through a characterization of real-world UAS flight datasets that there is significant opportunity to optimize data transmission in UAS settings by exploiting knowledge of UAS flight paths. Leveraging this insight, a system was developed which significantly out-performed an approach that does not exploit flight path information.

Fifth, using data from more than a hundred video publishers spanning two years, the project characterized video management planes, an area that has not received attention from the research community.The work showed that today's management plane practices may not be well suited for content syndication, in which syndicators license and redistribute content from a content owner, and  run video management planes that are independent from those of content owners. The resuls showed cases where, for the same content, owner's clients observe significantly different delivery performance than syndicator's clients. The project also showed that more integrated management planes between owners and syndicators can reduce CDN origin storage requirements.

The project forms the basis of the Ph.D dissertations of four students, and has also involved a woman graduate student, and an undergraduate student. The students have been trained in networking research, large-scale measurements and data analysis, and video streaming algorithms, and have received training in written and oral scientific communication. The project has led to six publications in premier scientific conferences including ACM Sigmetrics, IEEE ICNP, and ACM Internet Measurement Conference.The project has released three real-world datasets that can benefit other researchers.These include datasets of real-world video sessions, and a tool for generating throughput traces in UAS settings informed by real-world data collected by the project. The results of the project have been extensively communicated to many key players in the video streaming industry. The project team extensively interacted with researchers in Politecnico Di Torino, Italy who provied access to traffic data and expertise in traffic classification.
